original: A list of top frequently asked  Drupal interview questions  and answers are given below.
result: Below, you'll find a compilation of commonly asked Drupal interview questions and their corresponding answers.

original: Drupal is free, open-source content management framework written in PHP. Drupal is distributed under GNU General Public License.
result: Drupal is a content management framework that is free and open-source. It is written in PHP programming language and has been licensed under GNU General Public License.

original: Drupal is a framework which organize, manage and publish content easily and provides a lot of features of customization.
result: Drupal is a tool that allows for easy content organization, management, and publication. It offers numerous customizable features as well.

original: Following are some most commonly used PHP based CMS:
result: Below are some popular CMS systems that are built using PHP language:

original: Drupal is very easy to learn and handle. A user with nil programming skill can also handle the content management and customization of a Drupal's website. That's why Drupal is getting popular day by day.
result: Drupal has become increasingly popular due to its user-friendly interface, making it easy for individuals with little to no programming experience to manage and customize website content. Additionally, Drupal's accessibility has contributed to its growing popularity amongst users.

result: The specifications required for running Drupal 8 are as follows:

original: Web server: Apache, Nginx, or Microsoft IIS
result:
Here's a potential rephrased version: 

There are several options for web servers, including Apache, Nginx, and Microsoft IIS. Each of these servers has its own unique features and benefits.

original: Database: MySQL 5.5.3/MariaDB 5.5.20/Percona Server 5.5.8 or higher with PDO and an InnoDB-compatible primary storage engine, PostgreSQL 9.1.2 or higher with PDO, SQLite 3.6.8 or higher
result: The following relational database management systems are recommended for use: MySQL 5.5.3/MariaDB 5.5.20/Percona Server 5.5.8 or higher with PDO and an InnoDB-compatible primary storage engine, PostgreSQL 9.1.2 or higher with PDO, SQLite 3.6.8 or higher.

original: PHP 5.5.9 or higher
result: PHP version 5.5.9 or above is required.

original: PHP Memory: 60 MB
result: The amount of memory allocated to PHP is 60 MB.

original: Drupal has a lot of features:
result: Drupal boasts of a wide range of functionalities:

original: Simple and secure theme
result: A straightforward and reliable design that ensures users' safety.

original: Fast loading speed
result: Efficient loading time of a website or web page is an essential aspect that significantly impacts a user's browsing experience.

original: A module is a set of codes that extend Drupal features and functionality.
result: In Drupal, a module refers to a collection of code that enhances and expands the features and capabilities of the software.

original: Core modules:  These modules are included with the main download of Drupal, and you can turn on their functionality without installing additional software.
result: The fundamental modules of Drupal are the ones that come as part of the standard software download and do not require additional installation. You can activate these modules as needed.

original: Contributed modules:  These modules are downloaded from the Modules download section of drupal.org, and installed within your Drupal installation.
result: Downloadable extensions known as Contributed Modules can be obtained from the Modules section of the official Drupal website. After acquiring them, they can be integrated into your Drupal setup for additional functionality.

original: You can also create your own module "CustomModules" using PHP programming, and Drupal's module API.
result: You have the option to develop your own module called "CustomModules" using the module API of Drupal and PHP programming.

original: Some of the modules recommended are:
result: Here are some suggested modules:

original: Sub themes are just like other themes of Drupal but they have a little difference. Sub themes inherit the parent's theme. There are many sub themes that can be connected to their parents. A sub-theme can be a child of another sub-theme, and it can be branched and organized however you see fit. This is what gives sub-themes great potential.
result: Sub-themes are distinct themes in Drupal that have a unique feature of inheriting the characteristics of their parent theme. Although sub-themes share many similarities with other Drupal themes, they differ in that they have inherited attributes from their parent theme. Additionally, sub-themes are flexible in their organizational structure; they can be branched and categorized as desired. Consequently, sub-themes have excellent potential for customization.

original: PDO stands for PHP Data Object. It is a lean and consistent way to access databases. It facilitates developers to write portable codes easily. PDO is not an abstraction layer. It is more like a data access layer which uses a unified API.
result: PDO is an acronym for PHP Data Object, which is a simple and standardized method of accessing databases. It offers developers a convenient way to write code that can be easily transferred between different platforms. Unlike an abstraction layer, PDO is a data access layer that employs a single API.

original: DRUSH is a command line shell and UNIX scripting interface for Drupal.
result: DRUSH is an efficient tool for managing and interacting with Drupal via a command line shell and UNIX scripting interface. It allows for streamlined management of Drupal installations and saves time and effort for website administrators.

original: Yes. Drupal can run on command line by using DRUSH.
result: DRUSH enables Drupal to execute commands from the command line interface, meaning that Drupal can be run on the command line.

original: Ctools is a set of APIs and tools which is used to improve the developer experience.
result: Ctools refers to a collection of helpful tools and APIs that aid developers in their coding process, enhancing their overall experience.

original: Render arrays are the basic building blocks in Drupal. They provide you a structured way to programmatically change the content before it is displayed.
result: In Drupal, render arrays serve as fundamental units for constructing content. They offer a structured means of modifying the content before it gets presented on the website, enabling programmers to make changes programmatically.

original: Patches are the files that contain a list of differences between one set of files, and another. You can make changes like addition, deletion in codes through patches. Patches can also be used to make changes to another copy of the original or main file.
result: Patches refer to sets of files that list down the modifications one has made to an original file, which could include adding, deleting or editing code. These patches can be utilized to implement changes to another version of the same file, apart from the main or original file.

original: No. It is not possible to disable a core required module through Drupal admin.
result: It is not feasible to deactivate a core module that is needed to run Drupal via the administrative panel.

original: In Drupal database system, each type of information has its own database table. Different types of information will be stored in different database table. For example, nodes information is stored in nodes table.
result: In the Drupal database system, various kinds of information are saved separately into distinct database tables. As an instance, nodes information is stored in a dedicated table called nodes table.

original: Drupal supports MySQL/MariaDB, PostgreSQL, and in Drupal 7 SQLite.
result: Drupal has the capability to work with MySQL/MariaDB, PostgreSQL, and SQLite (only in Drupal 7).

original: To drop a table you can use db_drop_table in install file.
result: "When deleting a table in a database, you can utilize the db_drop_table function within an installation file."

original: Distributions are full copies of Drupal including Drupal core along with additional software such as modules, libraries and installation profiles.
result: Distributions refer to complete versions of Drupal that consist of Drupal core, as well as other software modules, libraries, and installation profiles.

original: Distributions are used for:
result: Distributions serve a variety of purposes such as providing a way to describe the probability of certain outcomes in a dataset and helping to model and analyze data.

original: The term weight in Drupal is used to order nodes. Nodes with lower weight will be at top of the list while nodes with heavier weight will be at lower position.
result: In Drupal, 'weight' refers to the way in which nodes are prioritized and listed. The weight assigned to a node determines its position in the list: nodes with a lower weight will appear at the top, while those with a higher weight will appear lower down.

original: The term cron is a daemon that executes commands at specified interval. Drupal cron executes commands or scripts automatically at specified interval.
result: The word "cron" refers to a computer program that carries out commands at pre-determined intervals. The Drupal content management system also has its own version of cron, which runs automatically at set intervals and executes various scripts and tasks.

original: Languages in which Drupal can be translated are:
result:
Here is a rephrased version:
Drupal is capable of being translated into a variety of languages.

original: The field API allows custom data fields to be attached to Drupal entities. Any entity type can use field API to make itself "fieldable" means allows fields to attach to it.
result: The field API in Drupal is a powerful feature that enables entities to add custom data fields according to their needs. By using field API, any entity type can make itself fieldable and easily allow fields to be attached to it.

original: Drupal treats all the stored content on its web site as nodes. Any piece of content like blog, article, page, etc is considered as node. Although, the comments are not stored as nodes but they are always connected to a node.
result: In Drupal, all of the content that is saved on the website is categorized as nodes. Any type of content such as blog posts, articles, or pages is considered a node in Drupal. However, comments are not stored as nodes themselves but they are always associated with a particular node.

original: The template.php file in the theme directory allows you to override a theme function.
result: The theme directory provides a file called template.php which enables you to modify a theme function by overriding it.

original: Drupal integrates well with external search engines such as Xapian, Apache solr if the built-in search engine does not meet your needs properly.
result: If the default search engine on Drupal does not meet your requirements, you can easily integrate it with external search engines like Xapian and Apache solr to enhance its functionality.

original: Hooks are Drupal API code which allows module to interact with Drupal core. Its module system is based on the hooks concept.
result: In Drupal, hooks are fundamental pieces of code in the API that enable modules to communicate with Drupal core. The module system in Drupal operates on the concept of hooks.

original: There are three ways to interact with Drupal search system by implementing:
result: There are three methods of utilizing the Drupal search system through implementation.

original: Be default, Drupal doesn't allow the insertion of PHP codes in its pages. To embed PHP codes, you need to activate a Drupal module called PHP filter. By default, this module remains disabled.
result: To incorporate PHP codes in Drupal, you must enable the PHP filter module, which is not active by default and allows the insertion of PHP codes in pages.

original: The Sections module allows applying different themes to different pages in a Drupal site.
result: With the Sections module, it is possible to assign unique styles to various pages of a Drupal website.

original: Drupal classifies its content which is called taxonomy and is implemented in the core Taxonomy module.
result: Drupal has a system for organizing its content, which is referred to as taxonomy. This taxonomy is built into the software through the Taxonomy module that is included in the core features.
